TITLE:  CCU INTERN PROGRESS NOTE
   Chief Complaint:  Intubated s/p cardiac arrest
   24 Hour Events:
   Patient did well overnight, kept on maintenance IVF at 75ml/hr.  Also
   febrile to 100.6, not on any antibiotics at this time.
   Some runs of non-sustained Vtach overnight.
   Allergies:
   Penicillins
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Ranitidine (Prophylaxis) - [**2159-6-25**] 11:38 PM
   Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) - [**2159-6-25**] 11:38 PM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:

   SpO2: 96%
   ABG: 7.45/36/95.[**Numeric Identifier **]/23/1
   Ve: 8.2 L/min
   PaO2 / FiO2: 271
   Physical Examination
   GENERAL - sedated, comfortable male on a ventilator
   HEENT - pupils slightly reactive, sclerae anicteric, MMM, Conjunctiva
   were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
   NECK - supple, no thyromegaly, no apparent JVD but difficult to assess
   b/c patient on neck brace, no carotid bruits
   LUNGS
 coarse breath sounds throughout the lungs, on ventilator
   HEART - PMI located in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. RRR,
   normal S1, S2. Systolic murmur II/VI near apex. No thrills, lifts. No
   S3 or S4.
   ABDOMEN - NABS, soft/NT/ND, no masses or HSM, no rebound/guarding. Abd
   aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.
   EXTREMITIES - WWP, no c/c/e, 2+ peripheral pulses (radials, DPs), No
   c/c/e. No femoral bruits.
   SKIN - no rashes or lesions. Slight skin breakdown behind neck where
   collar was rubbing.  Slight burn marks where defibrillator pads were on
   abdomen.
   LYMPH - no cervical, axillary, or inguinal LAD
   NEURO - responding to pain, not following commands, sedated.
   PULSES:
   Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
   Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
   Labs / Radiology
   243 K/uL
   12.0 g/dL

                             [**2159-6-25**]  09:24 PM
                             [**2159-6-25**]  09:34 PM
                             [**2159-6-26**]  04:23 AM
   WBC
   11.3
   10.8
   Hct
   37.1
   35.3
   Plt
   226
   243
   Cr
   0.8
   0.8
   TropT
   0.04
   TCO2
   26
   Glucose
   124
   135
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:12.4/23.3/1.0, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:[**2070-5-6**]/0.04 (decreased from 2909/6/0.04), ALT / AST:109/89
   (decreased from 129/116), Alk Phos / T Bili:69/1.8, Amylase /
   Lipase:/19, Differential-Neuts:90.2 %, Lymph:6.0 %, Mono:3.1 %, Eos:0.6
   %, Albumin:3.3 g/dL, LDH:506 IU/L, Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.4 mg/dL,
   PO4:1.9 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname 7331**] is a 64 YO M wtih history of MVP and bicuspid aortic
   valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation
   in cardiac enzymes and LFTs transfered for further work up.
   .
   #. Cardiac arrest - Unclear etiology, but patient was having
   wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The preciptiant of the cardiac
   arrest is still unclear and etiologies suggest arrhythmia (VFib
   specificallY) or seizure. Stroke with AFib is another posibility, but
   we cannot assess any deficits a this time given sedation.  Also
   possible it could be ischemia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Serial ECGs
   - Trend CE
   - Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1795**]: cardiac cath today to r/o CAD
   - Neurology consult today re: ?seizure and mental status off sedation
   -> cortical function given minimally responsive state
   .
   #. CAD - Patient with normal stress test 2 weeks prior, multiple ECG
   changes (right and left bunndle as above), Trop I of 2.24 and CK of
   ~5500 with negative MBI. He does not have any risk factors, was not on
   aspirin and did not have chest pain. This makes unlikley that he has
   CAD as presenting symptom.
   - Cardiac cath today
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Trend CE
   - Serial ECGs
   - Continue Metorpolol (increased to 50mg po/ng TID)
   - On simvastatin 20mg po daily
   - No indications for ACEI/[**Last Name (un) 284**] given not known CAD and most-likley
   increased CE after CPR
   - ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Plavix load given
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt currently with LBBB morphology, but RBBB in multiple
   ECGs at other hospital. Pt also has extensive ectopy. At this time his
   electrolytes are normal. No signs of ischemia. Dilated heart in
   echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF, bicuspid AS and mixomatous
   degeneration of mitral valve. [**Month (only) 11**] be going in and out of Atrial
   Fibrilation.
   - Repelte electrolytes PRN
   - Continue metoprolol 50 mg TID for now
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   - EP consult in AM
   - Discuss anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH. Will
   hold until CT scan negative.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of heart failure at this time. Preserved EF.
   .
   #. Fever - Pt was found down and s/p cooling protocol. WBC was high up
   to 14,000. No signs of infection on CXR and UA clean at OSH. Concern
   for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. Given no infiltrates
   will hold on antibiotics for now. Withdrawal is another consideration.
   Febrile to 100.6 last night.
   - FU U/A
   - FU CXR
   - FU Blood cultures
   - No antibiotics for now
   .
   #. Alcohol abuse - Pt with last drink 4 days ago. Has been getting
   ativan and valium. No signs of withdrawal at this time (HR, BP
   adequte), but difficult to assess given beta-blocker and sedated.
   - CIWA with ativan given shock liver; will hold for now pending neuro
   consult
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 7334**] LFTs - Pt with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the
   settinf of code and being found down.
   - Trend LFTs
   - BP management as above
   .
   #. Hematuria - Resolved. Most likely traumatic after Foley placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding feeds until extubation, no diet for 3 days so far
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines: 18 Gauge - [**2159-6-25**] 08:00 PM (PIV x 3 from OSH)
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SC heparin
   Stress ulcer: Ranitidine per NGT
   Bowel regimen: Colace/senna
   VAP:  HOB 30 degrees, mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Wife [**Name (NI) 288**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Known lastname 7331**]s Home [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7335**] & Cell
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7336**]
   Code status: Full code (confirmed with wife)
   Disposition:  CCU for now, cath today

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was intubated after a cardiac arrest. The patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, and had a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.7°C (99.9°F), HR 85 bpm, BP 127/69 mmHg, RR 18 breaths per minute, SpO2 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is on a ventilator with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes (CK 5500 IU/L, Troponin-T 0.04 ng/mL), abnormal LFTs (ALT 109 IU/L, AST 89 IU/L), and a normal complete blood count (CBC).
* Physical examination: The patient is sedated and comfortable, with coarse breath sounds throughout the lungs, a normal heart rhythm, and a preserved ejection fraction (EF) on echocardiogram.

The patient is at risk for several medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is currently on telemetry monitoring. He is also taking metoprolol and simvastatin, which may increase his risk of arrhythmias.
2. Infection: The patient has a fever and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia or pneumonitis due to his intubation.
3. Neurological complications: The patient is sedated and has a history of possible seizure, which may increase his risk of neurological complications.
4. Liver damage: The patient has elevated LFTs and is at risk for liver damage due to his cardiac arrest and possible ischemic hepatitis.
5. Hematuria: The patient has resolved hematuria, but may be at risk for further bleeding due to his cardiac catheterization.
6. Stress ulceration: The patient is at risk for stress ulceration due to his intubation and sedation.
7. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his immobility and is receiving prophylactic heparin.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Cardiac catheterization to rule out CAD
2. Telemetry monitoring for cardiac arrhythmias
3. Serial ECGs and trend CE to monitor cardiac enzymes
4. Neurology consult to assess possible seizure and cortical function
5. EP consult to discuss anticoagulation for AFib
6. Hold on antibiotics for now due to lack of infiltrates on CXR and UA
7. CIWA with ativan to manage possible withdrawal
8. Trend LFTs to monitor liver damage
9. BP management to prevent further liver damage
10. ICU care to manage the patient's complex medical condition.

   Mr. [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname 7331**] is a 64 YO M wtih history of MVP and bicuspid aortic
   valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation
   in cardiac enzymes and LFTs transfered for further work up.
   .
   #. Cardiac arrest - Unclear etiology, but patient was having
   wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The preciptiant of the cardiac
   arrest is still unclear and etiologies suggest arrhythmia (VFib
   specificallY) or seizure. Stroke with AFib is another posibility, but
   we cannot assess any deficits a this time given sedation.  Also
   possible it could be ischemia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Serial ECGs
   - Trend CE
   - Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1795**]: cardiac cath today to r/o CAD
   - Neurology consult today re: ?seizure
   .
   #. CAD - Patient with normal stress test 2 weeks prior, multiple ECG
   changes (right and left bunndle as above), Trop I of 2.24 and CK of
   ~5500 with negative MBI. He does not have any risk factors, was not on
   aspirin and did not have chest pain. This makes unlikley that he has
   CAD as presenting symptom.
   - Cardiac cath today
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Trend CE
   - Serial ECGs
   - Continue Metorpolol (increased to 50mg po/ng TID)
   - On simvastatin 20mg po daily
   - No indications for ACEI/[**Last Name (un) 284**] given not known CAD and most-likley
   increased CE after CPR
   - ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Plavix load given
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt currently with LBBB morphology, but RBBB in multiple
   ECGs at other hospital. Pt also has extensive ectopy. At this time his
   electrolytes are normal. No signs of ischemia. Dilated heart in
   echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF, bicuspid AS and mixomatous
   degeneration of mitral valve. [**Month (only) 11**] be going in and out of Atrial
   Fibrilation.
   - Repelte electrolytes PRN
   - Continue metoprolol 50 mg TID for now
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   - Echcoardiogram in AM to assess for WMA
   - EP consult in AM
   - Discuss anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH. Will
   hold until CT scan negative.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of heart failure at this time. Preserved EF.
   .
   #. Fever - Pt was found down and s/p cooling protocol. WBC was high up
   to 14,000. No signs of infection on CXR and UA clean at OSH. Concern
   for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. Given no infiltrates
   will hold on antibiotics for now. Withdrawal is another consideration.
   Febrile to 100.6 last night.
   - FU U/A
   - FU CXR
   - FU Blood cultures
   - No antibiotics for now
   .
   #. Alcohol abuse - Pt with last drink 4 days ago. Has been getting
   ativan and valium. No signs of withdrawal at this time (HR, BP
   adequte), but difficult to assess given beta-blocker and sedated.
   - CIWA with ativan given shock liver
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 7334**] LFTs - Pt with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the
   settinf of code and being found down.
   - Trend LFTs
   - BP management as above
   .
   #. Hematuria - Resolved. Most likely traumatic after Foley placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding feeds until extubation, no diet for 3 days so far
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines: 18 Gauge - [**2159-6-25**] 08:00 PM (PIV x 3 from OSH)

Summary:

The patient, a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, was intubated after a cardiac arrest. He was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and LFTs, and is being treated for possible cardiac arrest, CAD, and rhythm disturbances. The patient is currently on maintenance IVF at 75ml/hr and is febrile to 100.6. He has had some runs of non-sustained Vtach overnight.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and potential etiologies include arrhythmia, seizure, stroke, or ischemia.
2. CAD: The patient's cardiac catheterization today will help rule out CAD as a presenting symptom.
3. Rhythm Disturbances: The patient has a history of LBBB morphology, RBBB in multiple ECGs, and extensive ectopy. His electrolytes are normal, and he is being monitored for signs of ischemia.
4. Fever: The patient's fever is concerning for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis, and he is being monitored for signs of infection.
5. Withdrawal: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and recent use of Ativan and Valium makes withdrawal a possibility, although it is difficult to assess given his sedation and beta-blocker therapy.
6. Shock Liver: The patient's LFTs are elevated, and he is being monitored for signs of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.
7. Hematuria: The patient's hematuria has resolved, and it is likely traumatic after Foley placement.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and his treatment plan includes:

* Cardiac catheterization today to rule out CAD
* Serial ECGs and telemetry monitoring
* Trend CE and LFTs
* Neurology consult today to assess for seizure
* Echocardiogram in the morning to assess for WMA
* EP consult in the morning
* Discussion of anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH
* Holding antibiotics for now, pending further evaluation of infection
* Monitoring for signs of withdrawal and shock liver
* ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Mr. [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname 7331**] is a 64 YO M wtih history of MVP and bicuspid aortic
   valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation
   in cardiac enzymes and LFTs transfered for further work up.
   .
   #. Cardiac arrest - Unclear etiology, but patient was having
   wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The preciptiant of the cardiac
   arrest is still unclear and etiologies suggest arrhythmia (VFib
   specificallY) or seizure. Stroke with AFib is another posibility, but
   we cannot assess any deficits a this time given sedation.  Also
   possible it could be ischemia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Serial ECGs
   - Trend CE
   - Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1795**]: cardiac cath today to r/o CAD
   - Neurology consult today re: ?seizure
   .
   #. CAD - Patient with normal stress test 2 weeks prior, multiple ECG
   changes (right and left bunndle as above), Trop I of 2.24 and CK of
   ~5500 with negative MBI. He does not have any risk factors, was not on
   aspirin and did not have chest pain. This makes unlikley that he has
   CAD as presenting symptom.
   - Cardiac cath today
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Trend CE
   - Serial ECGs
   - Continue Metorpolol (increased to 50mg po/ng TID)
   - On simvastatin 20mg po daily
   - No indications for ACEI/[**Last Name (un) 284**] given not known CAD and most-likley
   increased CE after CPR
   - ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Plavix load given
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt currently with LBBB morphology, but RBBB in multiple
   ECGs at other hospital. Pt also has extensive ectopy. At this time his
   electrolytes are normal. No signs of ischemia. Dilated heart in
   echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF, bicuspid AS and mixomatous
   degeneration of mitral valve. [**Month (only) 11**] be going in and out of Atrial
   Fibrilation.
   - Repelte electrolytes PRN
   - Continue metoprolol 50 mg TID for now
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   - Echcoardiogram in AM to assess for WMA
   - EP consult in AM
   - Discuss anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH. Will
   hold until CT scan negative.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of heart failure at this time. Preserved EF.
   .
   #. Fever - Pt was found down and s/p cooling protocol. WBC was high up
   to 14,000. No signs of infection on CXR and UA clean at OSH. Concern
   for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. Given no infiltrates
   will hold on antibiotics for now. Withdrawal is another consideration.
   Febrile to 100.6 last night.
   - FU U/A
   - FU CXR
   - FU Blood cultures
   - No antibiotics for now
   .
   #. Alcohol abuse - Pt with last drink 4 days ago. Has been getting
   ativan and valium. No signs of withdrawal at this time (HR, BP
   adequte), but difficult to assess given beta-blocker and sedated.
   - CIWA with ativan given shock liver
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 7334**] LFTs - Pt with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the
   settinf of code and being found down.
   - Trend LFTs
   - BP management as above
   .
   #. Hematuria - Resolved. Most likely traumatic after Foley placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding feeds until extubation, no diet for 3 days so far
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was intubated following a cardiac arrest. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve. He was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and liver function tests (LFTs) after the cardiac arrest.

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 500 mL. He is febrile at 100.6°F and has a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL.

The patient's cardiac rhythm is currently sinus rhythm, but he has had episodes of wide-complex tachycardia and atrial fibrillation in the past. He has also had episodes of ventricular fibrillation, which is a potential cause of his cardiac arrest.

The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, with a bilirubin level of 1.8 mg/dL and an alkaline phosphatase level of 69 IU/L. His electrolyte levels are normal, but he has had episodes of hypokalemia in the past.

The patient's neurologic status is unclear due to sedation, but he is not following commands and is responding to pain.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and ventricular fibrillation increases his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias, which can lead to cardiac arrest or stroke.
2. Infection: The patient's febrile state and abnormal liver function tests suggest the possibility of an infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Ischemia: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and abnormal cardiac enzymes suggest the possibility of ischemia, which can lead to myocardial infarction or cardiac failure.
4. Liver failure: The patient's abnormal liver function tests and history of shock liver suggest the possibility of liver failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and death.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's mechanical ventilation and abnormal lung function tests suggest the possibility of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and death.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Cardiac catheterization to rule out coronary artery disease
2. Neurology consult to assess for seizure activity
3. Serial ECGs to monitor for cardiac arrhythmias
4. Trending of cardiac enzymes to monitor for myocardial infarction
5. Monitoring of liver function tests to monitor for liver failure
6. Monitoring of electrolyte levels to monitor for electrolyte imbalances
7. Management of fever to prevent infection
8. Management of pain to prevent withdrawal syndrome
9. Monitoring of respiratory status to prevent respiratory failure

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest remains unclear, and further workup is needed to determine the etiology. The patient's history of MVP, bicuspid aortic valve, and possible seizure and cardiac arrest suggest a high risk of recurrent cardiac arrest.
2. CAD: Although the patient's stress test was normal, the patient's ECG changes, elevated Troponin, and CK levels suggest possible CAD. Further cardiac catheterization is needed to rule out CAD.
3. Rhythm Disturbances: The patient's LBBB morphology and RBBB in previous ECGs suggest a high risk of arrhythmias. The patient's electrolytes are normal, but further monitoring and serial ECGs are necessary to detect any changes.
4. Fever: The patient's fever, despite no signs of infection on CXR and UA, suggests possible aspiration PNA or pneumonitis. Further investigation, including FU U/A, CXR, and blood cultures, is necessary to determine the cause of the fever.
5. Withdrawal: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and recent cessation suggest a high risk of withdrawal syndrome. Further monitoring and consideration of CIWA with Ativan are necessary.
6. Shock Liver or Ischemic Hepatitis: The patient's LFTs are elevated, suggesting possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis. Further monitoring and trend analysis of LFTs are necessary.
7. Hematuria: The patient's resolved hematuria is likely traumatic, but further investigation is necessary to rule out underlying kidney damage.
8. VAP: The patient's VAP prophylaxis regimen includes ranitidine, but further monitoring and adjustment of the regimen are necessary to prevent VAP.
9. ICU Care: The patient's ICU care plan includes nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and bowel regimen. Further monitoring and adjustment of these plans are necessary to ensure the patient's optimal care.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and further workup to determine the underlying causes of their cardiac arrest, CAD, rhythm disturbances, and other medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, who experienced a possible seizure and cardiac arrest, leading to elevation of cardiac enzymes and liver function tests (LFTs). The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is being treated for cardiac arrhythmia, anoxic brain injury, and other complications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Neurological status: The patient is unresponsive and has not improved despite being off sedation for 48 hours. A computed tomography (CT) scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.
* Cardiac status: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is currently being treated for cardiac arrhythmia. A dilated heart is seen on echocardiogram, with preserved ejection fraction (EF).
* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is stable, and his cardiac output is adequate.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is receiving fluids and diuretics to manage fluid overload.
* Hepatic status: The patient has shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, and his LFTs are trending down.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and cardiac enzymes suggests that he may be at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
* Anoxic brain injury: The patient's CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury, which can lead to long-term cognitive and neurological deficits.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further interventions to manage his respiratory function.
* Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and fluid overload suggest that he may be at risk for renal failure.
* Hepatic failure: The patient's shock liver or ischemic hepatitis may lead to further liver dysfunction and failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring on telemetry to assess for cardiac arrhythmias.
* Continuing to manage his cardiac status with medication and close monitoring.
* Monitoring his neurological status and considering further imaging studies to assess for anoxic brain injury.
* Managing his respiratory status with mechanical ventilation and close monitoring.
* Managing his hemodynamic status with fluids and diuretics.
* Monitoring his renal status and considering further interventions to manage fluid overload.
* Monitoring his hepatic status and considering further interventions to manage shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.

The patient's family should be informed of his condition and the potential complications that can arise. They should also be educated on the importance of close monitoring and follow-up care to manage the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU following a cardiac arrest and possible seizure. The patient's cardiac arrest was likely caused by a primary arrhythmia, and he has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve.

The patient's neuro status is of great concern, as he has decreased mental status, and his CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. He is at risk for anoxic brain injury due to his cardiac arrest and head trauma. The patient's EEG monitoring has been recommended to evaluate for nonconvulsive seizure activity.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, as he has had episodes of ectopy and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) that have responded to IV boluses of potassium. He has a dilated heart on echocardiogram with preserved ejection fraction, and his coronary arteries show minimal disease. He is being treated with metoprolol, simvastatin, and aspirin.

The patient's abdominal status is also concerning, as he has had a possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, and his LFTs are trending down but still slightly elevated.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 277, and he is being ventilated with a CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, with a heart rate of 95 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 116/73 mmHg.

The patient's nutritional status is being managed with repletion of fiber and glycemic control.

The patient's lines are in place, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP is being administered.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to remain in the CCU for now.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury, and he is at risk for further brain damage.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT, and he is at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Shock liver or ischemic hepatitis: The patient's LFTs are trending down but still slightly elevated, and he is at risk for further liver damage.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is being ventilated, and he is at risk for respiratory failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient has a possible infection, and he is at risk for sepsis.
6. Bleeding: The patient has a possible coagulopathy, and he is at risk for bleeding.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient is at risk for pulmonary embolism due to his immobility and the presence of a central venous catheter.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was intubated after a cardiac arrest. The patient has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve. The cardiac arrest is still unclear, but possible etiologies include arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, and stroke with atrial fibrillation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Neurological status: The patient is unresponsive and has not improved off sedation for 48 hours. A CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. The patient has muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology.
* Cardiac status: The patient has a preserved EF, but has had episodes of ectopy and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia, which have responded well to IV boluses of potassium. The patient is also taking metoprolol and ASA.
* Respiratory status: The patient is on a ventilator with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and FiO2 of 40%. The patient's ABG shows a pH of 7.49, PCO2 of 31, and PO2 of 111.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 116/73 mmHg, heart rate is 95 bpm, and cardiac output is normal.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL, and the patient is receiving fluids and diuretics as needed.
* Hepatic status: The patient has shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, and the patient's LFTs are trending down.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Seizures: The patient's neurological status is concerning for seizures, and the patient is at risk for non-convulsive seizure activity.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had episodes of ectopy and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia, and the patient is at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is on a ventilator, and the patient's respiratory status is concerning for respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has a fever, and the patient is at risk for sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's cardiac status and the use of anticoagulants.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine is elevated, and the patient is at risk for renal failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring the patient's neurological status and cardiac rhythm.
* Continuing to manage the patient's respiratory status with the ventilator.
* Repleting electrolytes as needed.
* Continuing the patient's medications, including metoprolol and ASA.
* Monitoring the patient's LFTs and renal function.
* Considering further cardiac testing, such as a cardiac MRI, to further evaluate the patient's cardiac status.
* Considering further neurological testing, such as an EEG, to further evaluate the patient's neurological status.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who was admitted with possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He was intubated and transferred to the ICU for further workup. The patient's cardiac arrest was precipitated by wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM, and the etiology is still unclear. The patient has signs of anoxic brain injury on CT scan, and his neurological status has not improved despite being off sedation for 48 hours. He has muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology. The patient has also developed fever, which is likely secondary to aspiration pneumonitis, and has been responding well to tylenol.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's neurological status has not improved, and he is at risk of developing further brain injury or even death.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded to IV boluses of K+. He is at risk of developing further cardiac arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's fever is likely secondary to aspiration pneumonitis, and he is at risk of developing pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukopenia suggest that he may be at risk of developing sepsis.
5. Liver damage: The patient has shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, and his LFTs are trending down. He is at risk of developing further liver damage.
6. Cervical spine injury: The patient's CT scan did not show evidence of fracture, but he is at risk of developing a ligamentous injury or other cervical spine injury.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on ventilator support, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure.
8. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, and he is at risk of developing cardiac failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation and analgesia as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust medication as needed to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Continue to treat the patient's fever and monitor for signs of pneumonia.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust medication as needed to prevent further liver damage.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cervical spine and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further injury.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator support as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medication as needed to prevent cardiac failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who suffered a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He was transferred to the ICU for further workup. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been off sedation for 48 hours. His neuro status remains unchanged, with no improvement in responsiveness, and a CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. The patient has muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements, possibly due to central neurological injuries.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure activity: The patient's EEG is being monitored, and no evidence of seizures has been detected at this time. However, the patient's neuro status remains unchanged, and seizure activity is a possibility.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's fever and low-grade fevers may be indicative of aspiration pneumonia, which is a concern given his intubation status.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. Monitoring for cardiac arrhythmias is necessary, and EP recommendations have been made.
4. Left to right shunt: The patient's CT scan showed an aneurysmal interatrial septum without evidence of intracardiac shunting, which is likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return. An MRI is recommended to further characterize this finding.
5. Cervical spine injury: The patient's CT scan showed no evidence of fracture, but the collar cannot be removed without an MRI or patient verbalization of pain.
6. Shock liver or ischemic hepatitis: The patient's LFTs are trending down, but remain elevated. Monitoring for signs of liver dysfunction is necessary.
7. Cardiac failure: The patient's EF is preserved, but monitoring for signs of cardiac failure is necessary given his history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve.
8. Withdrawal syndrome: The patient's history of EtOH abuse makes withdrawal syndrome a possibility. CIWA has been recommended to monitor for withdrawal symptoms.
9. Infection: The patient's fever and low-grade fevers may be indicative of infection, which is a concern given his intubation status and history of EtOH abuse. Blood cultures have been ordered, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP is being continued.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, who was admitted to the ICU after a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He has been on mechanical ventilation for 24 hours and is currently on CPAP 10/5 with a SpO2 of 93%. His neuro status is unchanged, with no improvement in responsiveness or response to stimuli. His CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. He has been off sedation for 48 hours and is still unresponsive.

The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has a dilated heart with preserved EF on echocardiogram. He has had episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. He is also experiencing left-to-right shunt, likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, and has minimal CAD.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9°C, blood pressure of 136/78 mmHg, and heart rate of 85 bpm. His respiratory rate is 21 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 93%. He has a slight skin breakdown behind his neck and burn marks from defibrillator pads.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is still on mechanical ventilation, and there is a risk of respiratory failure if his condition deteriorates.
2. Neurological complications: The patient's neuro status is unchanged, and there is a risk of further neurological deterioration or even death if he does not improve.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has a dilated heart with preserved EF. There is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias or even cardiac arrest if his condition deteriorates.
4. Infection: The patient has a fever, and there is a risk of infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Skin breakdown: The patient has a slight skin breakdown behind his neck, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving nutrition through a PICC line, but there is a risk of nutritional deficiencies if his condition deteriorates.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolytes are being monitored, but there is a risk of electrolyte imbalance if his condition deteriorates.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's neuro status and adjust his sedation and pain management as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and adjust his antibiotics as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's skin breakdown and adjust his wound care as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his nutrition as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte status and adjust his electrolyte management as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve. He is currently intubated and on a ventilator, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 5. He has a moderate to severe encephalopathy with cortical and subcortical structures affected, as evidenced by his EEG and CT scan. He has a posterior circulation distribution abnormality, which may warrant further investigation.

The patient's cardiovascular status is stable, with a preserved ejection fraction (EF) and no signs of heart failure. He has a dilated heart on echocardiogram, which is likely secondary to his bicuspid aortic valve and mitral valve prolapse. He has had episodes of ectopy and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) in the past, which have responded to IV boluses of potassium.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 97%. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on a ventilator.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated cardiac enzymes and liver function tests (LFTs), consistent with cardiac and liver injury. His white blood cell count is 11.3, and his platelet count is 73.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs suggest a high risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and cardiac death.
2. Neurological complications: The patient's moderate to severe encephalopathy and posterior circulation distribution abnormality suggest a high risk of neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, and brain death.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for respiratory complications, including pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
4. Liver complications: The patient's elevated LFTs suggest a high risk of liver complications, including liver failure, jaundice, and bleeding.
5. Renal complications: The patient's elevated creatinine level suggests a high risk of renal complications, including acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.
6. Infection: The patient's febrile response and elevated white blood cell count suggest a high risk of infection, including pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, with serial ECGs and telemetry.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status closely, with serial neurological exams and imaging studies as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, with serial arterial blood gas (ABG) analyses and oxygen saturation measurements.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function closely, with serial LFTs and bilirubin levels.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function closely, with serial creatinine levels and urine output measurements.
6. Consider ordering additional imaging studies, such as a head CT or MRI, to further evaluate the patient's posterior circulation distribution abnormality.
7. Consider ordering additional laboratory tests, such as a troponin level or a D-dimer level, to further evaluate the patient's cardiac and pulmonary status.
8. Consider ordering additional medications, such as anticoagulation therapy or antibiotics, to prevent or treat potential complications.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications and improve his outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, who was transferred to the ICU after a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He is currently unresponsive, on a ventilator, and has a moderate to severe encephalopathy involving cortical and subcortical structures. The EEG suggests a posterior circulation distribution abnormality, which may warrant further investigation.

The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has a dilated heart with preserved EF on echocardiogram. He has had episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. The patient is also at risk for a left-to-right shunt due to anomalous pulmonary venous return.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 11.3
* Hct: 37.1
* Plt: 73
* Cr: 0.8
* TropT: 0.04
* TCO2: 24
* Glucose: 124
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.4/24.4/1.0, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 495/3/0.02, ALT/AST: 91/91, Alk Phos/T Bili: 68/0.9, Amylase/Lipase: 19, Differential-Neuts: 90.2%, Lymph: 6.0%, Mono: 3.1%, Eos: 0.6%, Albumin: 3.3 g/dL, LDH: 506 IU/L, Ca++: 8.9 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL, PO4: 3.8 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Neurological: The patient's encephalopathy may worsen, leading to further neurological deficits or even brain death.
2. Cardiac: The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has a dilated heart with preserved EF. He may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory: The patient is on a ventilator, and his respiratory status may deteriorate, leading to respiratory failure.
4. Infection: The patient has a fever, and there is a concern for aspiration pneumonia or pneumonitis.
5. Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding or malnutrition.
6. Hematological: The patient's platelet count is low, and he may be at risk for bleeding complications.
7. Endocrine: The patient's glucose levels are slightly elevated, and he may be at risk for hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
8. Renal: The patient's creatinine levels are slightly elevated, and he may be at risk for acute kidney injury.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his sedation and analgesia accordingly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs, and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust his antibiotic therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his nutrition plan accordingly.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hematological status and adjust his platelet transfusion plan accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's endocrine status and adjust his glucose control plan accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal status and adjust his fluid management plan accordingly.

Potential next steps:

1. Consider performing an MRI or MRA to further investigate the patient's posterior circulation distribution abnormality.
2. Consider performing a cardiac catheterization to further investigate the patient's cardiac status.
3. Consider performing a gastrointestinal workup to further investigate the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms.
4. Consider performing a hematological workup to further investigate the patient's hematological status.
5. Consider performing an endocrine workup to further investigate the patient's endocrine status.
6. Consider performing a renal workup to further investigate the patient's renal status.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who was admitted to the ICU after a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He has been intubated and is currently on a ventilator. His neurological status is unchanged, with moderate to severe encephalopathy and posterior circulation distribution abnormality on EEG. He has been off sedation for 72 hours and is showing minor withdrawal to pain and more EEG activity.

The patient has had several complications, including a left-to-right shunt, possible Afib, and an abnormal MRI. He has also had episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. His cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has been diagnosed with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.

The patient's medical team is concerned about several potential complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM, or stroke with Afib.
2. Neurological recovery: The patient's neurological status is still uncertain, and his EEG shows signs of anoxic brain injury.
3. Fever: The patient has had low-grade fevers, which may be due to aspiration PNA or pneumonitis.
4. Rhythm: The patient's heart rhythm is abnormal, with dilated heart and preserved EF, and he has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT.
5. Left-to-right shunt: The patient has a left-to-right shunt, which may be secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM, or stroke with Afib.
2. Neurological recovery: The patient's neurological status is still uncertain, and his EEG shows signs of anoxic brain injury.
3. Fever: The patient has had low-grade fevers, which may be due to aspiration PNA or pneumonitis.
4. Rhythm: The patient's heart rhythm is abnormal, with dilated heart and preserved EF, and he has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT.
5. Left-to-right shunt: The patient has a left-to-right shunt, which may be secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust medication as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and adjust antibiotics as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's left-to-right shunt and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Consider performing a cardiac MRI to further characterize the patient's cardiac anatomy and function.

Note: The patient's family should be informed of the potential complications and recommendations, and a family meeting should be scheduled to discuss the patient's condition and prognosis.

   EEG. He is 3L positive length of stay.   Ge started Lasix 20mg IV x 2
   yesterday but did not meet goal of -500 cc.
   - Standing Lasix 40mg po BID to diurese, as receiving tube feeds and
   not self-diuresing
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - EP recs: wait to do further investigtion/tx until neurological
   recovery
   - ECGs in AM
   - Monitor lytes and replete as needed
   .
   #Neuro status: Improvement in neuro status with minor withdrawal to
   pain and more EEG activity; off sedation for 72 hours. CT with signs of
   anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. Presence of muscle
   fasiculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology, but
   possibly due to central neurological injuries.  Have ruled out other
   causes of encephalopathy including B12, TSH, NH3.
   - F/U Neuro recs on prognosis
   - Family consented for MRI/MRA; will do this tomorrow to assess neuro
   status
   - CT showed no C-spine fx, cannot r/o ligamentous injury; continue
   collar until neck cleared if awakens or via MRI
   - Continue to monitor physical exam, responsiveness, response to
   stimuli
   .
   #. Fever - Concern for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. WBC
   increased to 11.3 today.  Febrile to 100.2 in last 24 hours and with
   low-grade fevers. Responds well to tylenol. Unlikely to represent
   withdrawal in pt with hx of EtOH abuse b/c not hypertensive or
   tachycardic.
   - Sputum Cultures: oral flora, last chest xray [**6-27**]
   - FU Blood cultures
   - Continue Levofloxacin (Day 1=[**6-27**]) for total of 7 days; today is day
   [**4-12**].
   .
   #. Rhythm - Dilated heart in echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF,
   bicuspid AS and mixomatous degeneration of mitral valve. Continued
   having episodes of ectopy/NSVTlast night and this morning, which have
   responded well to IV boluses of K+. Initial discussion of possible
   Afib; has had no episodes since admission; Increased ectopy (NSVT)
   overnight.
   - Replete electrolytes PRN
   - Increased metoprolol from 75 mg TID to 100 mg TID
   - EP recommendations if becomes more frequent or stops responding to K
   boluses
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   .
   #Left to Right Shunt: Most likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary
   venous return. MRI recommended to further characterize but not possible
   with intubation.
   - TTE showed aneurysmal interatrial septum without evidence of
   intracardiac shunting.
   - If awakens, suggest cardiac MRI
   .

 Cath with minimal CAD. CE
s are down

   - Stop simvastatin 20mg po daily b/c clean coronaries and LDLc is 91
   - ASA 325 mg Daily

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently intubated and minimally responsive. The patient has been in the ICU for 3 days and has undergone various tests and treatments.

The patient's neurological status has shown some improvement, with minor withdrawal to pain and more EEG activity. However, the patient remains unresponsive and has a CT scan showing signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.

The patient has a fever, which is being treated with Tylenol, and has increased white blood cell count. The patient's rhythm is abnormal, with episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. The patient has also been experiencing left-to-right shunt, which is likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return.

The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are trending down, and the patient is receiving tube feeds. The patient's electrolytes are being monitored and repleted as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on a ventilator, which increases the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Neurological damage: The patient's anoxic brain injury may lead to long-term neurological damage or even death.
3. Infection: The patient's fever and increased white blood cell count suggest the possibility of infection, which can be life-threatening.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's abnormal rhythm may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which can be life-threatening.
5. Left-to-right shunt: The patient's left-to-right shunt may lead to heart failure or other cardiovascular complications.
6. Ischemic hepatitis: The patient's LFTs are trending down, which may indicate ischemic hepatitis, a potentially life-threatening condition.
7. Malnutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds, which may not be sufficient to meet their nutritional needs, leading to malnutrition.
8. Wound complications: The patient has a slight skin breakdown behind the neck and burn marks from the defibrillator pads, which may lead to wound complications.

To mitigate these risks, the patient's care team should continue to monitor his vital signs, neurological status, and cardiac function, and provide supportive care to manage his symptoms and prevent complications.

   but we still cannot assess any deficits at this time given
   unresponsiveness, although there may be a suggestion of PCA infarct on
   EEG. He is 3L positive length of stay.   Ge started Lasix 20mg IV x 2

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who suffered cardiac arrest and was intubated. He remains minimally responsive and has been on mechanical ventilation. His neurological status has shown some improvement over the past week, with minor withdrawal to pain and more EEG activity. However, he still has anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, and his muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements are unclear in etiology.

The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, suggesting possible cardiac injury. He has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, and his echocardiogram shows a dilated heart with preserved EF.

The patient's respiratory support is ongoing, with a Vt set at 500 mL and a PS of 10 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 96%, and his ABG shows a pH of 7.51, PaO2 of 298, and PaCO2 of 25.

The patient's blood cultures are pending, and he is receiving antibiotics for possible pneumonia. His WBC count is 11.3, and his temperature is 100.2°F.

The patient's cardiac rhythm is stable, with no episodes of Afib since admission. His electrolytes are being monitored and repleted as needed.

The patient's cervical spine is stable, with a CT scan showing no fracture. However, he is still wearing a collar until his neck is cleared by MRI.

The patient's alcohol abuse history is being monitored, and he is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's fever and WBC count suggest the possibility of pneumonia.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has a history of cardiac injury.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's anoxic brain injury and muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements suggest the possibility of further neurological decline.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory support is ongoing, and he may be at risk for further respiratory decline.
5. Infection: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and he is at risk for further infection.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac rhythm is stable, but he may be at risk for further arrhythmias.
7. Cervical spine instability: The patient's cervical spine is stable, but he may be at risk for further instability if his neck is not cleared by MRI.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   EEG. He is 3L positive length of stay.   Ge started Lasix 20mg IV x 2

   - Standing Lasix 40mg po BID to diurese, as receiving tube feeds and

   recovery

   pain and more EEG activity; off sedation for 72 hours. CT with signs of
   anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. Presence of muscle
   fasiculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology, but
   possibly due to central neurological injuries.  Have ruled out other

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who suffered a cardiac arrest, intubated, and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 100.2°F (37.9°C)
* Heart rate: 78 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 100/65 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's neurological status is as follows:

* Pupils: 5mm, reactive
* Sclerae: anicteric
* MMM: present
* Conjunctiva: pink
* No pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa
* Off sedation, moderately responsive, with 5mm pupils, and spontaneous eye movement
* + Upgoing Babinski

The patient's cardiac status is:

* Cardiac arrest: unclear etiology, possibly arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia at 220 bpm
* Dilated heart in echocardiogram, preserved EF, bicuspid AS, and mitral valve mixomatous degeneration
* Episodes of ectopy/NSVT, responded well to IV boluses of K+
* Increased ectopy (NSVT) overnight

The patient's respiratory status is:

* On ventilator, coarse breath sounds throughout the lungs, no crackles/wheezes appreciated
* RSBI: 110
* PIP: 15 cmH2O
* PEEP: 5 cmH2O
* FiO2: 40%

The patient's laboratory results are:

* WBC: 11.3 K/uL
* Hct: 38.4%
* Plt: 428
* Cr: 1.0 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.02
* TCO2: 27
* Glucose: 139 mg/dL
* Other labs: Ca++: 9.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL, PO4: 4.4 mg/dL

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Lasix 40mg po BID to diurese
* Monitor on telemetry
* EP recs: wait to do further investigation/tx until neurological recovery
* ECGs in AM
* Monitor lytes and replete as needed
* F/U Neuro recs on prognosis
* Family consented for MRI/MRA; will do this tomorrow to assess neuro status
* Continue to monitor physical exam, responsiveness, response to stimuli
* Sputum cultures: oral flora
* FU Blood cultures
* Continue Levofloxacin for total of 7 days
* Replete electrolytes PRN
* Increased metoprolol from 75 mg TID to 100 mg TID
* EP recommendations if becomes more frequent or stops responding to K boluses
* Serial ECGs
* Telemetry

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Cardiac failure
* Respiratory failure
* Neurological decline
* Infection (aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis)
* Left to right shunt
* Cervical spine injury
* Pump failure
* Hepatic failure
* Renal failure

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is currently the CCU.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest. He remains intubated and minimally responsive with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, or stroke with AFib. Further investigation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and prevent future episodes.
2. Neurological status: The patient's neurological status is still uncertain, and further imaging studies such as MRI/MRA are needed to assess the extent of anoxic brain injury. The presence of muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements may indicate central neurological injuries.
3. Fever: The patient's fever is likely due to aspiration pneumonia or pneumonitis, and further investigation with sputum cultures and blood cultures is needed to determine the cause. The patient's WBC count has increased, and he is at risk of developing sepsis.
4. Rhythm: The patient's rhythm is unstable, with episodes of ectopy and NSVT. Further management with IV boluses of K+ and increased metoprolol may be necessary to control his rhythm.
5. Left to Right Shunt: The patient's shunt is likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, and further characterization with MRI is needed. If the patient awakens, a cardiac MRI may be necessary to further assess his cardiac function.
6. CAD: The patient's CAD is minimal, but further management with metoprolol and ASA may be necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Pump failure: The patient's pump function is preserved, but further monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of heart failure.
8. Cervical spine: The patient's cervical spine is unstable, and further imaging studies such as MRI are needed to assess the extent of any damage. If the patient awakens, the collar may need to be removed, and further management with physical therapy may be necessary.
9. Alcohol abuse: The patient's history of alcohol abuse may indicate a risk of withdrawal, and further management with CIWA may be necessary.
10. LFTs: The patient's LFTs are trending down, but further monitoring is necessary to detect any signs of liver damage.

In summary, the patient's condition is complex and requires further investigation and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who was admitted after a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week. The patient has a cardiac arrest with unclear etiology, and possible stroke with AFib is another possibility. He has left upper extremity tremors of unknown etiology, and an EEG is pending. The patient has a fever, and the etiology is unclear, with oral flora on sputum culture. He has dilated heart in echocardiogram with preserved EF, and has had episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to increased metoprolol. The patient has a stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of the cervical collar and unable to remove until negative MRI. He is intubated on moderate settings, and RSBI is 87. The patient has a left to right shunt, most likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, and a cardiac MRI is recommended. He has minimal CAD, and CE's are down. The patient's LFTs are trending down, and he has shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and possible etiologies include arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, and stroke with AFib. Further investigation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and prevent future episodes.
2. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status is still improving, but he remains minimally responsive and intubated. Further evaluation with EEG and MRI is needed to determine the cause of his neurological deterioration and to monitor for any further changes.
3. Fever: The patient's fever is unclear, and further investigation is needed to determine the etiology and to prevent further complications.
4. Skin breakdown: The patient has a stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of the cervical collar, and further evaluation with MRI is needed to determine the extent of the damage and to plan for further treatment.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated on moderate settings, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his respiratory failure and to plan for weaning from the ventilator.
6. Left to right shunt: The patient has a left to right shunt, most likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, and further evaluation with cardiac MRI is needed to determine the extent of the shunt and to plan for further treatment.
7. Shock liver or ischemic hepatitis: The patient's LFTs are trending down, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his shock liver or ischemic hepatitis and to plan for further treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and to treat any arrhythmias that occur.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and to treat any further changes or deterioration.
3. Continue to investigate the etiology of the patient's fever and to treat any further complications.
4. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's skin breakdown and pressure ulcer.
5. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's respiratory failure and to plan for weaning from the ventilator.
6. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's left to right shunt and to plan for further treatment.
7. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's shock liver or ischemic hepatitis and to plan for further treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, who was admitted with a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with a slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week. The patient has been experiencing various medical complications, including left upper extremity tremors, fever, cardiac rhythm disturbances, and skin breakdown.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure of 105/77 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. His laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin level, and abnormal liver function tests.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and heart medications. He is also receiving tube feeds and has a central line and arterial line in place.

Potential medical complications:

1. Seizure disorder: The patient's history of possible seizure and cardiac arrest, as well as his current left upper extremity tremors, suggest that he may be at risk for seizure activity.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and abnormal laboratory results, such as elevated white blood cell count and abnormal liver function tests, suggest that he may have an underlying infection.
3. Cardiac rhythm disturbances: The patient's cardiac rhythm disturbances, including wide-complex tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation, may indicate a high risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Skin breakdown: The patient's skin breakdown and pressure ulcer around the edge of his cervical collar may require further evaluation and management.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure, as indicated by his RSBI of 87, may require further evaluation and management, including possible tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation.
6. Left-to-right shunt: The patient's left-to-right shunt, as suggested by his echocardiogram, may require further evaluation and management, including possible cardiac MRI.
7. Cervical spine injury: The patient's cervical spine injury, as suggested by his CT scan, may require further evaluation and management, including possible MRI and removal of his cervical collar.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his medications as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's skin breakdown and pressure ulcer, and consider further evaluation and management.
4. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's respiratory failure, including possible tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation.
5. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's left-to-right shunt, including possible cardiac MRI.
6. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's cervical spine injury, including possible MRI and removal of his cervical collar.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust his medications and treatments as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition is as follows:

**Cardiovascular:**

* The patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs.
* The cardiac arrest was likely caused by arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM (VFib specifically), or stroke with AFib.
* The patient has a dilated heart in echocardiogram with preserved EF, bicuspid AS, and mitral valve mixomatous degeneration.
* The patient has had episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which responded well to IV boluses of K+.
* The patient is on metoprolol 100mg TID and ASA 325 mg daily.

**Neurological:**

* The patient is minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.
* The patient has an anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, as seen on CT scan.
* The patient has muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology, possibly due to central neurological injuries.
* The patient has left upper extremity tremors of unsure etiology.
* The patient's EEG is pending, and an MRI/MRA is planned today to assess neuro status.

**Respiratory:**

* The patient is intubated on moderate settings, with a RSBI of 87.
* The patient's lung status is appropriate for weaning, but given his depressed mental status, intubation will be held for now.
* Consideration is being given to tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) due to prolonged intubation.

**Infectious:**

* The patient has a fever, which is concerning for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis.
* The patient's WBC has decreased to 9.6, and they are afebrile in the last 24 hours.
* The patient's sputum cultures are pending, and blood cultures are pending.

**Other:**

* The patient has skin breakdown around the collar and is unable to remove it until a negative MRI is obtained.
* The patient's respiratory failure is being managed with intubation and mechanical ventilation.
* The patient has a left-to-right shunt, which is likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return.
* The patient's CAD is minimal, and they have been catheterized with clean coronaries.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest
* Increased risk of respiratory failure or pneumonia
* Development of skin breakdown or pressure ulcers
* Increased risk of infection, particularly respiratory or bloodstream infections
* Further neurological decline or seizures
* Development of cardiac failure or heart failure
* Need for further surgical intervention, such as tracheostomy or percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG)

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who suffered a cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, or stroke with AFib. Continuous monitoring and further investigation are necessary to determine the cause.
2. Neurological status: The patient's neurological status is still uncertain, and further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of his brain injury. The presence of muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology is a concern.
3. Fever: The patient's fever is concerning, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause. Aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis are possible diagnoses, and cultures are pending.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated on moderate settings, and his lung status is appropriate for weaning. However, his depressed mental status and potential for cardiac complications may necessitate continued mechanical ventilation.
5. Skin breakdown: The patient has developed a stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of his cervical collar, which requires careful management to prevent further deterioration.
6. Left-to-right shunt: The patient's TTE showed aneurysmal interatrial septum without evidence of intracardiac shunting, but a left-to-right shunt is suspected. MRI is recommended to further characterize this finding.
7. CAD: The patient has minimal CAD, and his CE levels are down. However, he is on metoprolol and ASA, which may need to be adjusted.
8. Pump failure: The patient's EF is preserved, but his cardiac function may still be compromised.
9. Cervical spine: The patient's CT scan showed no evidence of fracture, but he is unable to remove his cervical collar without MRI or verbalizing pain. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the extent of his cervical spine injury.
10. Liver function: The patient's LFTs are trending down, indicating possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis. Close monitoring is necessary to prevent further deterioration.

In summary, the patient requires continued close monitoring and management to address these potential complications and optimize his care.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who suffered a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He remains intubated and minimally responsive, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week. He has a positive fluid balance, with input exceeding output, and is receiving 20 mg IV lasix to manage this. His cardiac enzymes and LFTs are trending down, and he is being monitored for signs of heart failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, or stroke with AFib. Further investigation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and prevent future episodes.
2. Neurological Status: The patient's neurological status is improving, but he remains minimally responsive. Further EEG results are pending, and an MRI/MRA has been recommended to further characterize the patient's condition.
3. Fever: The patient's fever is concerning for aspiration PNA or pneumonitis, and further investigation is needed to determine the cause. Sputum cultures and blood cultures are pending.
4. Rhythm: The patient has experienced episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to increased metoprolol. Further monitoring and treatment are needed to prevent future episodes.
5. Skin Breakdown: The patient has developed a stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of his cervical collar, and further treatment is needed to prevent further breakdown.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and has a moderate RSBI. Weaning from the ventilator is being held due to his depressed mental status.
7. Left to Right Shunt: The patient has a likely secondary left to right shunt due to anomalous pulmonary venous return. An MRI has been recommended to further characterize this condition.
8. CAD: The patient has minimal CAD, and his lipid profile is normal. Further monitoring and treatment are needed to prevent future cardiac events.
9. Pump Failure: The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are trending down, indicating that his heart is not failing at this time.
10. Cervical Spine: The patient's cervical spine is stable, but further evaluation is needed to determine if he has a ligamentous injury.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs to ensure that his heart is not failing.
2. Further investigate the patient's neurological status and potential causes of his seizures.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and treat any underlying infections.
4. Monitor the patient's rhythm and treat any further episodes of ectopy/NSVT.
5. Continue to treat the patient's skin breakdown and prevent further breakdown.
6. Wean the patient from the ventilator when his mental status improves.
7. Consider further evaluation of the patient's left to right shunt and potential treatment options.
8. Monitor the patient's CAD and lipid profile to prevent future cardiac events.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's pump failure and treat any signs of heart failure.
10. Consider further evaluation of the patient's cervical spine and potential treatment options for any ligamentous injuries.
